issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: Second AM attempt launched for session mode and recovery disabled for certain cases

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description: There are times when a user only wants to run an application with one attempt.  Examples would be cases where the second AM attempt is not prepared to handle recovery or will accidentally corrupt state (e.g.: by re-executing something from scratch that should not be).  Prior to YARN-614 setting the max attempts to 1 would guarantee the app ran at most one attempt, but now it can run more than one attempt if the attempts fail due to a fault not attributed to the application.
fields.summary: AMs only intended to run one attempt can be run more than once

comments.body: See TEZ-3426 for an example of an app framework that was depending upon maxattempts=1 really meaning at most one attempt.  I suspect there are other cases where app frameworks are not properly prepared to run more than one attempt correctly and those frameworks or their users are setting max app attempts=1 to avoid the issues.  After YARN-614 that won't always be the case.  Filing this ticket in case we want to consider interpreting maxattempts=1 as a special-case.
+1, thanks [~jlowe] for the JIRA. This should be configurable. YARN should be configurable to count or not the System Failures.

Here's a patch that implements the "one max attempt really means one attempt total" policy.  I can't think of a case where a user or framework explicitly setting max attempts to 1 ever expects the AM to run more than once.  This typically is set when running the AM more than once will actually be problematic.
